metadata.name: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets
metadata.comment: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via CommandLine

batch.sql: SELECT * FROM process_activity WHERE time BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AND (activity_id = 1 AND (contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('[system.net.webrequest]::create')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('curl ')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('invoke-restmethod')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('invoke-webrequest')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('iwr ')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('net.webclient')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('resume-bitstransfer')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('start-bitstransfer')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('wget ')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('winhttp.winhttprequest'))))

output.summary: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via CommandLine

metadata.objective: False positive: Use of Get-Command and Get-Help modules to reference Invoke-WebRequest and Start-BitsTransfer. References: https://4sysops.com/archives/use-powershell-to-download-a-file-with-http-https-and-ftp/, https://blog.jourdant.me/post/3-ways-to-download-files-with-powershell, https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/bitstransfer/add-bitsfile?view=windowsserver2019-ps
